message_1: Find all entire functions $f$ such that $f(0) = 1$ and $|f(z)| \leq e^{|\text{Im}(z)|}$ for all $z$.
message_2:
We will use the Cauchy estimates to solve this problem. Let $f(z)$ be an entire function such that $|f(z)| \leq e^{|\text{Im}(z)|}$ for all $z$. Let $z_0 = x_0 + iy_0$ be any complex number, and let $R > 0$ be any positive real number. Consider the circle $C$ with center $z_0$ and radius $R$. By the Cauchy integral formula, we have

$$f^{(n)}(z_0) = \frac{n!}{2\pi i} \oint_C \frac{f(z)}{(z-z_0)^{n+1}} dz$$

for any non-negative integer $n$. Taking the absolute value of both sides, we get

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \frac{n!}{2\pi} \oint_C \frac{|f(z)|}{|z-z_0|^{n+1}} |dz|$$

Now, we use the given inequality $|f(z)| \leq e^{|\text{Im}(z)|}$ and the fact that $|z-z_0| \geq R$ for all $z \in C$ to obtain

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \frac{n!}{2\pi} \oint_C \frac{e^{|\text{Im}(z)|}}{R^{n+1}} |dz| \leq \frac{n!}{2\pi} \oint_C \frac{e^{|\text{Im}(z_0)|+R}}{R^{n+1}} |dz|$$

Since the last expression does not depend on $z$, we can integrate it directly to get

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \frac{n!}{2\pi} \cdot \frac{e^{|\text{Im}(z_0)|+R}}{R^{n+1}} \cdot 2\pi R = \frac{n!}{R^n} e^{|\text{Im}(z_0)|+R}$$

Now, let $R \to \infty$. We have

$$|f^{(n)}(z_0)| \leq \lim_{R \to \infty} \frac{n!}{R^n} e^{|\text{Im}(z_0)|+R} = 0$$

for all $n \geq 1$. This implies that $f^{(n)}(z_0) = 0$ for all $n \geq 1$, which means that $f(z)$ is a constant function. Since $f(0) = 1$, we have $f(z) = 1$ for all $z$. Thus, the only entire function satisfying the given conditions is $f(z) = 1$.
